instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.820-3208: What is 820-3208? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
Green light is missing.
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> pin 1 = 19v, Pin 2: 0.027mv

What is pulling it down?

I have changed the <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> and same problem.

could it be the chip <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> that is pulling it down? ive changed that one as well.

I removed all the caps connected to ground under <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.

any ideas pls why <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> gets 19v on side pin1 but nothing on pin2..??? I have changed to new resistor 3 times already. Weird!

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
Why don't you post 820-xxxx code?
In your picture, only 6x 4.7uF caps and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> are connected after <DIODE>D6905</DIODE>.
Check diode mode to ground on that point, before apply power.
Also check if <DIODE>D6905</DIODE> is not shorted too.
Did you replace <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> with correct value?

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
sorry, ive been off the forum a while so forgot to post the board nr.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3208</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Macbook Air

<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> is original and has the same value (10).. Ive changed the diode as well. In case its pulling it down. Still doesnt work. very strange! Could it be somehthigng inside ethe board thats messing it up?

never seen before a Resistor having volateg on one pin and nothing on the other even with a new resistor.

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
"Check diode mode to ground on that point"
I was expecting you will post it here.
10 ohms resistor should have voltage on both sides; unless is blown.

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> both pin showing "OL" open line in diode mode.

I injected voltage and tried to hunt for short. No short from what I could see.

The 10 ohm resistor is new.. Its very weird..

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message: There is a short on this capacitor pad <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>. Even though i took away the capacitor. its still shorted to ground. How is that possible? must be a short under/inside the board itself. The cap was burnt before I took it off. That cap is attached to <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>. Could it be <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> isbeing pulled down and thats why the Diode also cant pull the voltage?

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
There are 6x 4.7uF and <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> connected.
Cannot be so dificil to find the culprit; even removing one by one...

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
That's a strange thing.. There must be an internal short on the board.. I have removed all the caps. all of them 6x 4.7uF. One of the shorts the one I posted <CAPACITOR>C6991</CAPACITOR>, that pad is shorted to ground.which is the line for <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL>. So how do I go about to fix that if it's an internal short on the motherboard? is it possible. or should I just tell the customer this board is not fixable. It seems so

I will try to remove the IC <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> again and see if the short is gone and revert back to you asap.

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
First remove <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
If still short, look if any pad is damaged.
Then scratch the board, try to isolate that pad.
You may need to cut off the trace in 2 points and make a bypass.

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message:
1. i detached <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>, i have not short/continuity to ground.
2. I placed another <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> from donor board.
3. I changed the resistor 10ohm resistor before diode <DIODE>D7005</DIODE>. And the 10ohm resistor(<RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>) broke right away. What could be the cause for that?

threads.title: pp3v42 not coming on.
threads.message: Do you still have short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL> when <CHIP>U6990</CHIP> is removed?
